markdownRemark.excerpt: What is undefined? Undefined is a special value in programming that refers to a variable or object that has not been defined or given a value yet. When…
markdownRemark.html:
What is undefined?

Undefined is a special value in programming that refers to a variable or object that has not been defined or given a value yet. When accessing a value that hasn't been given a value, the result is "undefined". In programming, this is an indicator of a bug or a typo, as it means that the code is trying to access something that doesn't exist.

Understanding undefined in JavaScript

In JavaScript, undefined is the default value of uninitialized variables, parameters which have not been assigned a value and elements in an array which have not been assigned a value. It is also a return value for functions that have not explicitly set a return value (in which case the return value is undefined).

When a variable is declared, but not initialized (i.e. given a value), the value of that variable is undefined.

Below is an example of an uninitialized variable in JavaScript:

var myVar;
console.log(myVar); // prints undefined

In the code above, we declare a variable called myVar, but we do not initialize it (i.e. give it a value). Therefore, the value of myVar is undefined. When we print out the value of myVar to the console, the result is “undefined”.

Life Hacks to Deal with Undefined Errors in JavaScript

If you’re getting “undefined” errors in JavaScript, it means something is not correctly defined in your code. Here are some tips to help you debug and fix the problem:

Check for typos

Typos are common cause of errors in code, and the same goes for JavaScript. Make sure you’ve spelt everything correctly when declaring variables and objects in your code. Even a single letter out of place can lead to unexpected results.

Check variable declarations

If you’re accessing a variable that is undefined, make sure the variable has been declared. JavaScript is case-sensitive, so make sure the variable name is spelt exactly the same way when you declare it and access it.

Check initializations

If you’re dealing with undefined values, make sure the appropriate values have been initialized. Variables, objects and elements in an array must have a value assigned to them before you try to access them.

Check function parameters

If you’re trying to access a function parameter that is undefined, make sure the parameter has been given a value when the function is called.

Check function return values

If the value of a function is undefined, make sure the function has a return statement in it, and that the return statement is referencing a value.

Use a debugger

Sometimes it can be hard to spot the cause of the undefined error just by looking at the code. In these cases, try using a debugger to step through your code and help you locate the undefined value.
